pageData.text: In this activity, students will use a tuning fork to generate in a tube that is open at one end. Students will identify the length of tube necessary for the sound of the tuning fork to be amplified through resonance, which is an increase in the amplitude of a at a specific . Through an understanding of the properties of waves and the conditions necessary to establish standing waves in this scenario, students will calculate the speed of sound in air at room temperature, and the of sound generated by the tuning fork.

pageData.text: Many instruments rely on changing the length of a tube to change the <button class='glossary-text'>frequency</button> of sound it produces. In most cases, the musician controls sound by changing their fingering or manipulating the tube to alter its length. But, in the San Franscisco Bay, a there is a musical instrument that is played by the ocean itself. Constructed on concrete jetty, the Wave Organ has a series of PVC and concrete tubes placed at different elevations<sup>1</sup>. As the waves come in, they crash against the end of the tubes and generate sound waves. The length of the tube determines the frequency of the sound wave and the pitch that the listener will hear.  As the tide comes in, the pipes fill partially with water, changing the amount of air in the tube and the pitch of the sound it creates. Because the water is constantly moving, the length of air in the pipes, number of sound waves produced, and which pipes are creating sounds are also constantly changing. This means that the listener will hear a unique “song” every time they listen to it.

1Konstantinovsky, M. (2023, March 8). San Francisco's wave organ plays with the tides. HowStuffWorks Science.
https://science.howstuffworks.com/engineering/structural/san-francisco-wave-organ.htm

pageData.altText: A series of three concrete pipes bent at an angle on the shore near a body of water. The pipes are each buried in the ground at one end and extend up and out toward the water at the other end.

pageData.text: Whenever someone sings or strums a guitar, are formed. If you have ever seen a doctor for an , they are using technology built upon a scientific understanding of waves to look inside your body. When ships use SONAR (SOund NAvigation Ranging) to detect objects under the waves or to measure the water’s depth, this is another example of how we use waves in our everyday lives. Animals use waves, too. Bats, whales and dolphins, for example, all use a form of sonar, called , to locate object by reflected sound.

Earthquakes are a form of traveling waves that many people are familiar with. These <button class='glossary-text'>seismic waves</button> are waves of energy that travel through Earth and arrive at the surface and are a mix of wave types.

Waves can transmit energy over great distances. Seismic waves generated by earthquakes can cause extensive damage; scientists use their knowledge of seismic waves to locate the epicenter of an earthquake. Sound and light are transmitted through waves. Waves can also carry complex information over a long distance; for example, . Some radios can send and receive complex signals and broadcast them over great distances. In this activity, you will calculate the speed of sound in air and apply some basic knowledge of waves to determine the of sound generated by a tuning fork.

A wave is a propagation of energy due to a rhythmic disturbance in a or through space. A medium is the material through which a wave travels. , such as waves in water, can only travel through a medium composed of some form of matter. Sound waves are mechanical and can travel through a gas, such as the air in earth’s atmosphere, liquid, and solid matter, but not through a vacuum.

A mechanical wave is transmitted when the molecules of a medium, such as air or water, move or vibrate in a repeating or oscillating motion. The particles of the medium generally remain in their original positions and vibrate back and forth, but the energy of the wave travels outward from the wave source.

can be classified as transverse or longitudinal. In a , the particles of the move or vibrate in a direction that is perpendicular to the direction of the . A group of people performing “the wave” in a stadium is a good example of a transverse wave. People move their arms up and down (vertically), and the wave travels horizontally around the stadium. When a string on a musical instrument, such as a guitar or piano, is plucked or struck, the molecules in the strings vibrate in one direction, whereas the energy in the wave travels along the length of the string.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Fingers strumming metal strings on an acoustic guitar. The topmost of the strummed guitar strings is blurry due to its vibrational movement.

pageData.text: Sound travels in a <button class='glossary-text'>longitudinal wave</button>, also called a <button class='glossary-text'>compression wave</button>. When a sound wave is generated, the molecules of the medium vibrate in a direction parallel to the direction of the wave, but do not travel with the wave, remaining in the same location. When a sound is generated, e.g., by the tuning fork in this activity, the air near the source vibrates, causing a disturbance in the surrounding air molecules that travels outward in all directions. However, the air molecules near the source and along the wave generally remain in their original locations.
Longitudinal mechanical waves travel through solids, liquids, and gases; however, transverse waves only travel through solid or liquid matter.

The intensity and of a wave are functions of the wave source, whereas the speed of the wave is determined by the medium through which the wave travels. To better understand waves, consider the diagram in Figure 2.

pageData.altText: Figure 2: Diagram of a waveform, showing the wave’s amplitude, wave height, and wavelength

pageData.text: The horizontal line is called the rest position. This is where the particles in the rest until disturbed by the energy from the . The distance labeled “A” is the amplitude of the wave. The amplitude of the wave is directly related to the intensity, or acoustic energy, of the sound. For a sound wave, greater amplitude means louder sound. The amplitude is the distance from the rest position to the position of greatest displacement. The position of greatest displacement above the rest position, or the highest point on the wave, is the . The position of greatest displacement below the rest position is the . The wave height (WH) is twice the amplitude. The distance between any two identical points (i.e., two crests or two troughs) on a waveform is the and is represented by the Greek letter lambda (λ). In depictions of waveforms, the wavelength is usually depicted between two crests, as shown in .

The waveform in Figure 2 can represent any kind of wave. The amplitude and wavelength provide enough information to analyze the wave. You may have seen sound waves represented by this type of waveform on an oscilloscope or computer screen.
In a sound wave, which is a , the air molecules move together in regions called , and spread apart in regions called (Figure 3).

pageData.altText: Figure 3: A diagram of a sound wave, showing wavelength, compressions, and rarefactions

pageData.text: Another important property of is . The frequency is the rate at which the particles in the vibrate. Frequency is measured in Hertz (Hz; cycles per second, cycles/s, cycles × s-1). Try tapping an object, such as a pencil, on a surface, such as a table, at a rate of one tap per second. That is a frequency of 1 Hz. The inverse of wave frequency is the of the wave. If you tap the pencil at a frequency of 2 Hz or two taps per second, the period, or time between taps is 0.5 seconds. What is the highest frequency at which you can tap the pencil? The tuning fork in this kit has a frequency of 2,048 Hz. Humans can hear sounds in a frequency range of 20–20,000 Hz. Anything above the range of human hearing is called , and anything below is called . A dog whistle makes an ultrasonic sound that is too high for humans to hear, but within the audible range for dogs. As people age, the ability to hear the higher frequencies diminishes.
The velocity, or speed, of a wave is related to the and frequency as described in the equation:

pageData.altText: Equation 1: vector v equals f times lambda

pageData.text: where v is velocity in meters/s; f is frequency in Hz, and λ is wavelength, measured in meters.
For example, consider a wave with a wavelength of 0.5 m and a frequency of 27 Hz.

v = (0.5 m)(27 Hz)
v = 13.5 m/s

pageData.question: What is the frequency of a wave when the speed of the wave is 27 m/s and the wavelength is 4 m?

options.text: 10 Hz
27 Hz
4 Hz

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Use the formula v = fλ where v is velocity in meters/s; f is frequency in Hz, and λ is wavelength, measured in meters. 27 m/s = f (4 m) Solving for f gives us a frequency of 6.75 Hz

pageData.question: What is the period of a wave with a frequency of 10 Hz?

options.text: 1 s

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The period is the inverse of a wave frequency.  1/10 = 0.1 s

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The distance between any two identical points (i.e., two crests or two troughs) on a waveform is the wavelength and is represented by the Greek letter lambda (λ). Another important property of waves is frequency. The frequency is the rate at which the particles in the medium vibrate. Frequency is measured in Hertz (Hz; cycles per second, cycles/s, cycles × s-1). Try tapping an object, such as a pencil, on a surface, such as a table, at a rate of one tap per second. That is a frequency of 1 Hz. The inverse of wave frequency is the period of the wave. If you tap the pencil at a frequency of 2 Hz or two taps per second, the period, or time between taps is 0.5 seconds. The velocity, or speed, of a wave is related to the wavelength and frequency as described in the equation: v = fλ where v is velocity in meters/s; f is frequency in Hz, and λ is wavelength, measured in meters.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The distance between any two identical points (i.e., two crests or two troughs) on a waveform is the wavelength and is represented by the Greek letter lambda (λ). Another important property of waves is frequency. The frequency is the rate at which the particles in the medium vibrate. Frequency is measured in Hertz (Hz; cycles per second, cycles/s, cycles × s-1). Try tapping an object, such as a pencil, on a surface, such as a table, at a rate of one tap per second. That is a frequency of 1 Hz. The inverse of wave frequency is the period of the wave. If you tap the pencil at a frequency of 2 Hz or two taps per second, the period, or time between taps is 0.5 seconds. The velocity, or speed, of a wave is related to the wavelength and frequency as described in the equation: v = fλ where v is velocity in meters/s; f is frequency in Hz, and λ is wavelength, measured in meters.

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Waves</button> exhibit many phenomena:

text: : Waves that reflect off solid objects.
: These waves diffract, or bend, around solid objects. An example of this is waves bending when passing through a gap, such as ocean waves passing between barrier islands.

: These waves interact with other waves. Imagine two instruments, such as trumpets, that are slightly out of tune, or have a slightly different pitch. Both trumpets play the same note, but the wave forms leaving each instrument are out of sync. The result is an oscillation in the intensity or loudness of the sound. Two sound waves result in a tone that has “beats” of higher and lower volume.

: At certain frequencies, a wave source may create waves that reflect back from one end of a and interfere with waves emanating from the source. A wave pattern is established where every point on the wave has a constant amplitude. A simple demonstration of a standing wave can be created with a rope or string. Tie a rope to a post or other immovable object. Pull the rope tight and then move it rhythmically up and down. Vary the speed of movement until the rope generates a constant wave form like the one shown in . The wave pulses travel from the wave source (your hand) to the post and reflect back. At a particular , the wave appears to stand still. In this example, the frequency depends on the linear density of the rope (mass per unit length; g/cm) and the tension. If you are having trouble setting up a standing wave with a rope, try adjusting the tension.

pageData.text: Where the wave forms cross, there is no displacement of the rope. These points are called . The rope is maximally displaced halfway between two nodes. These points are called . Because you are moving the rope at one end, that end is an antinode. The end at which the rope is anchored is a node. Try changing the frequency of the wave. Each new frequency will be associated with a different standing wave pattern, with different numbers of nodes and antinodes. These frequencies and the associated wave patterns are called .

Figure 4 shows how standing waves are established in an air column in a tube that is open at both ends. Each harmonic is an integral multiple of the first harmonic, or fundamental frequency. If the velocity of air is known and the length of the column can be measured, the frequency of each harmonic can be calculated.

pageData.altText: Figure 4: Diagram depicting how standing waves are established in an air column in a tube that is open at both ends

pageData.text:
The variables in the equations here are:f =
L = length of the column
v = velocity of air in column
λ =

Figure 5 shows how are established in a tube that is closed at one end. There will be a at the closed end of the tube and an at the open end. Whenever the frequency of the is an odd-numbered integer of the fundamental frequency, a standing wave will be established in the tube.

In the following activity, you will measure the speed of sound in air. Using the tuning fork as a sound source and a tube, one end of which is submerged in water in a graduate cylinder, you will adjust the length of the air column in the tube until a standing wave is established. When the standing wave is set up, the tube will resonate, which amplifies the sound slightly. You will then be able to calculate the wavelength of the standing wave.

pageData.altText: Figure 5: Diagram depicting how standing waves are established in an air column in a tube that is closed at one end

pageData.question: Which of the following parts of this standing wave is a node?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Where the wave forms cross is a node.

imageData.altText: Two waveforms intersecting such that the crests and troughs of each waveform are exactly opposite the other waveform. The point at which the two waveforms are furthest apart at the left end of the diagram is labeled 1. The next point at which the two waveforms are furthest apart to the right of label 1 is labeled 2.  A point at which the waveforms intersect is labeled 3. The distance between a point of maximum displacement and a point of intersection is labeled 4. The distance betwen 2 points of maximum displacement is labeled 5.

pageData.question: You have created a standing wave by tying a long rope to a pole and moving the rope up and down at a certain frequency. Which part of this standing wave demonstration represents a node?

options.text: the end of the rope attached to the pole
the end of the rope in your moving hand
the distance between crests of adjacent waves on the rope
the depth of the wave from crest to trough
the point of maximum displacement on the rope

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Because you are moving the rope at one end, that end is an antinode. The end at which the rope is anchored is a node.

imageData.altText: A hand holding a rope by one end. The rope is attached to a pole at the other end and is in the shape of a standing wave.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: At certain frequencies, a wave source may create waves that reflect back from one end of a medium and interfere with waves emanating from the source. A wave pattern is established where every point on the wave has a constant amplitude. A simple demonstration of a standing wave can be created with a rope or string. At a particular frequency, the wave appears to stand still. Where the wave forms cross, there is no displacement of the rope. These points are called nodes. The rope is maximally displaced halfway between two nodes. These points are called antinodes. Because you are moving the rope at one end, that end is an antinode. The end at which the rope is anchored is a node. Changing the frequency of the wave creates a different standing wave pattern with a different number of nodes and antinodes. Such a frequency and its associated wave pattern is called a harmonic.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: At certain frequencies, a wave source may create waves that reflect back from one end of a medium and interfere with waves emanating from the source. A wave pattern is established where every point on the wave has a constant amplitude. A simple demonstration of a standing wave can be created with a rope or string. At a particular frequency, the wave appears to stand still. Where the wave forms cross, there is no displacement of the rope. These points are called nodes. The rope is maximally displaced halfway between two nodes. These points are called antinodes. Because you are moving the rope at one end, that end is an antinode. The end at which the rope is anchored is a node. Changing the frequency of the wave creates a different standing wave pattern with a different number of nodes and antinodes. Such a frequency and its associated wave pattern is called a harmonic.

pageData.altText: A map of the procedural workflow of the investigation. Before beginning, you will find a quiet location and measure and mark the clear plastic tube. In activity 1, you will calculate the speed of sound at room temperature. Then, you will assemble the graduated cylinder and tube apparatus. Next, you will strike the tuning fork and listen for sound amplification in the tube. If you do not hear amplification, adjust the length of the air in the tube until you do hear sound amplification. Then, measure the distance from the end of the tube to the water. Next, adjust the length of air in the tube to the next point at which you can hear sound amplification. Do this until you have measure for 3 amplification points. Then, calcualte the wavelength of each tube length. Next, calculate the speed of sound for each wavelength. Finally, calculate the percent difference between the speed of sound at room temperature and the speed of sound for the given wavelengths.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: What is the amplitude in a wave?

options.text: The distance between the rest position and the crest.
The frequency of the wave.
The distance between a crest and a trough.
The distance between two crests.
The length of a wave.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following statements is specific to a transverse wave?

options.text: The particles in the wave move perpendicular to the direction of the wave.
The particles in the wave move parallel to the direction of the wave.
The amplitude of the wave is always the same as the frequency.
The waves always travel through a vacuum.
The wave signal creates compressions.

assestmentData.question: What determines the speed of a wave?

options.text: Speed is determined by the medium through which the wave travels.
Speed is determined by the period of the wave.
Speed is determined by the frequency of the wave.
Speed is determined by the wavelength.
Speed is determined by the amplitude of the wave.

assestmentData.question: What happens to the particles in a sound wave?

options.text: The particles vibrate in the direction of the wave, but do not travel with it.
The particles stay motionless in a sound wave.
The particles travel perpendicular to the wave and do not travel with it.
The particles travel perpendicular to the wave and travel with it.
The particles vibrate in the direction of the wave and travel with it.

assestmentData.question: What are the areas called in a sound wave where air molecules are spread apart?

options.text: rarefactions
harmonics
troughs
crests
compressions
A wave which bends around a solid object.
A wave that reflects off a solid object.
A wave which interacts with other waves.
A wave which increases in amplitude.
A wave which travels in a straight line.

assestmentData.question: What is the speed of the wave when the wavelength is 0.02 m and the frequency is 1000 Hz?

options.text: 20 m/s
10 m/s
50 m/s
A wave reflecting off a solid object.
A wave passing through a gap.
A wave which is dispersed.
A wave with an increased wavelength.
A wave with increased compressions.

Read through the activities.
Obtain all materials.
Clean the work space.

Go to a quiet location with enough work space to place the graduated cylinder on a flat surface. Strike the tuning fork against your hand and hold it at arm’s length. If you cannot hear the tuning fork, move to a quieter location.
Use your ruler and permanent marker to mark the entire length of the clear plastic tube at 1–cm intervals. Allow time to dry.

In Activity 1, you will use a graduated cylinder filled with water, a plastic tube and a tuning fork to generate sound <button class='glossary-text'>waves</button> at different <button class='glossary-text'>wavelengths</button>. You will then compare the speed of sound at room temperature to the calculated speed of sound for each wavelength.

pages.title:
A
  Standing Wave in a Tube Open at One End (12 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
  Standing Wave in a Tube Open at One End (12 steps)

pageData.text: Calculate the speed of sound in the surrounding atmosphere. Measure the temperature of the room using the thermometer, and use Equation 2.

pageData.altText: Equation 2: vector v sub s equals 331.4 plus 0.6 times T sub c

pageData.text:
where
vs = the speed of sound in meters per second (m/s) 331.4 m/s = the speed of sound in air at freezing temperatures0.6 is a constant with dimensions of m/s/°C and Tc = the temperature of the room in degrees Celsius.To convert from Fahrenheit to Celsius, use the formula °C = (°F − 32) × 5/9.Record TC and vs values in Data Table 1.
Assemble the graduated cylinder by placing the cylinder in the base.
Fill the graduated cylinder to the top with water.
Place the plastic tube in the cylinder. The submerged end is the closed end of the resonance tube, and the end above the surface of the water is the open end.
Strike the tuning fork on the palm of your hand or a book, and hold the vibrating tuning fork about 2 cm (~¾ in) above the mouth of the plastic tube.
Raise the plastic tube, increasing the length of the air column in the tube, while keeping the tuning fork about 2 cm above the mouth of the tube.

Listen for the point at which the plastic tube amplifies the sound from the tuning fork. It may be necessary to strike the tuning fork again during the experiment if the sound becomes too faint, and it may be necessary to move the tube up and down to reach to find the exact point where the sound from the tuning fork is amplified.
Measure the distance from the open end of the tube to the water. This is the length of ¼ of one . Record this value (L1) in Data Table 1.

Continue moving the tube upward, further extending the length of the air column, until you reach the next point where the sound from the tuning fork is amplified. This is the length of ¾ of one wavelength (see Figure 6). Record this value (L2) in Data Table 1.

pageData.altText: Figure 6: An illustration of a tube with one open end and one closed end; the formulas for the length and wavelength are given

pageData.text: Move the tube upward again until you reach the next point where the sound from the tuning fork is amplified. This is the length of ⁵/₄ of one wavelength. Record this value (L3) in Data Table 1.
Complete Data Table 1, using the speed of sound in the air (vs) to calculate the length of the wavelength, λ.
Calculate the percent difference between the values you calculated for the speed of sound using the closed tube (from ) and Equation 2 using the following equation:

pageData.altText: equation percent difference equals begin absolute value begin fraction first value minus second value over open parenthesis begin fraction first value minus second value over two end fraction close parenthesis end fraction end absolute value times 100 percent

text: Dispose of the water.
Dry the tube, tuning fork, and the graduated cylinder.
Return all materials to the equipment kit.

In activity 1, you will calculate the speed of sound at room temperature. Then, you will assemble the graduated cylinder and tube apparatus. Next, you will strike the tuning fork and listen for sound amplification in the tube. If you do not hear amplification, adjust the length of the air in the tube until you do hear sound amplification. Then, measure the distance from the end of the tube to the water. Next, adjust the length of air in the tube to the next point at which you can hear sound amplification. Do this until you have measure for 3 amplification points. Then, calcualte the wavelength of each tube length. Next, calculate the speed of sound for each wavelength. Finally, calculate the percent difference between the speed of sound at room temperature and the speed of sound for the given wavelengths.

data.title: Antinode
data.content: A point of maximum displacement on a waveform

data.title: Compression
data.content: An area on a compression wave where molecules move together

data.title: Compression wave
data.content: See longitudinal wave

data.title: Crest
data.content: The position of greatest displacement above the rest position; the highest point of the wave

data.title: Diffraction wave
data.content: A wave that diffracts or bends around solid objects

data.title: Echo wave
data.content: A wave that reflects off solid objects

data.title: Echolocation
data.content: The location of objects by reflected sound; it is used by animals such as dophins and bats

data.title: Frequency
data.content: The rate at which the particles in the medium vibrate

data.title: Harmonic
data.content: A wave with a fundamental frequency that is a positive integer multiple of a fundamental frequency

data.title: Infrasound
data.content: Any frequency of sound that is below human hearing

data.title: Interference wave
data.content: A wave that interacts with other waves

data.title: Longitudinal wave
data.content: A type of mechanical wave in which the molecules of the medium vibrate in a direction parallel to the direction of the wave, but do not travel with the wave; also known as a compression wave

data.title: Mechanical wave
data.content: A wave that is transmitted by molecules of a medium (such as air or water) that move or vibrated in a repeating or oscillating pattern

data.title: Medium
data.content: The material through which a wave travels

data.title: Node
data.content: A point of no displacement on a waveform

data.title: Period
data.content: The inverse of the wave frequency; the time it takes for one full wavelength to pass

data.title: Radio wave
data.content: An electromagnetic wave used for long distance communication

data.title: Rarefaction
data.content: An area on a compression wave where molecules spread apart

data.title: Seismic wave
data.content: A wave of energy that travels through Earth

data.title: Standing wave
data.content: A wave the reflects back upon itself and creates a pattern where every point on the wave is a constant amplitude

data.title: Transverse wave
data.content: A type of mechanical wave in which the particles in a medium move or vibrate in a direction that is perpendicular to the direction of the wave

data.title: Trough
data.content: The position of greatest displacement below the rest position; the lowest point of the wave

data.title: Ultrasound
data.content: Any frequency of sound that is above human hearing

data.title: Wave
data.content: A propogation of energy due to a rhythmic disturbance in a medium or through space

data.title: Wavelength
data.content: The distance between any two identical points on a waveform
